tn.text: a small stream of water flowing naturally from the Earth

tn.ref: passed on by hundreds and by thousands
tn.text: "divided their men into groups; some groups had one hundred soldiers and some groups had one thousand soldiers" (see UDB)

tn.ref: David and his men passed on in the rear guard with Achish
tn.text: The groups of hundreds and thousands passed on first, then Achish and his helpers, and then David, his men, and the other Philistine soldiers, who were guarding Achish.

tn.ref: What are these Hebrews doing here?
tn.text: Possible ways to translate this rhetorical question as a statement are AT: 1) "You should not have allowed these Hebrews, our enemies, to be here with us." or 2) "Tell us who these Hebrews are." (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_rquestion]])

tn.ref: Is not this David ... these years, and I have found ... this day?
tn.text: Another possible translation is "Is not this David, ... these years? I have found ... this day." The rhetorical question can be translated as a statement. AT: "You should know that this is David ... these years. I have found ... this day." (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_rquestion]])

tn.ref: I have found no fault with him
tn.text: This can be stated in positive form. AT: "I know of nothing that he has done wrong" or "I am very pleased with him" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_litotes]])

tn.ref: do not let him go with us into battle
tn.text: "do not let his army join with our army against our enemies"

tn.ref: For how else could this fellow make peace with his master? Would it not be with the heads of our men?
tn.text: This rhetorical question can be translated as a statement. AT: "The best way for David to make peace with his master would be by killing our soldiers!" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_rquestion]])

tn.ref: Is this not David of whom they sang one to another in dances, saying, 'Saul ... ten thousands'?
tn.text: This rhetorical question can be translated as a statement. AT: "You should not trust David—he is the one of whom they sang one to another in dances, saying, 'Saul ... ten thousands'!" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_rquestion]])
This is an idiom.  "As certainly as Yahweh lives" or "This is a true statement" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_idiom]])

tn.ref: your going out and your coming in with me in the army is good
tn.text: "I am happy to have you go out and come in with me and my army" or "It is good that you go everywhere with me and my army"
David speaks as if Achish were another person so that Achish will think David respects him. AT: "you, my master and king" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_pronouns]])
"even though that is true, this is more important: the princes" or "however, the princes"
The reader should understand that Achish is speaking of Saul.
